docs.lead_paragraph: ON early-morning boat crossings from the Connecticut shore to the Plum Island Animal Disease Center off the North Fork of Long Island, Peter W. Mason opens his laptop computer and goes to work organizing the day ahead. For Dr. Mason, a 44-year-old microbiologist from Killingworth, Conn., the job has never seemed more urgent. He directs a 20-member team at the isolated island laboratory in research aimed at developing a new, more widely acceptable vaccine for foot-and-mouth disease, a vaccine that would stop or quickly contain an outbreak of the highly contagious animal virus.

docs.lead_paragraph: After a year of proposals and counterproposals, the member nations of the World Trade Organization have finally agreed to begin negotiations in May on freer trade in agricultural goods. An agenda for the talks was approved late last week. But there was broad skepticism that talks on so contentious an issue could succeed without a whole new round of comprehensive trade negotiations being convened.

docs.lead_paragraph: PUTTING Slobodan Milosevic on public trial and forming a ''truth and reconciliation'' commission to examine his rule, suggested his successor Vojislav Kostunica last week, would help the Serbs achieve ''social catharsis.'' The notion seemed reasonable. Given all the horrors of Mr. Milosevic's 13-year rule, a few months of public testimony and revelations would surely help begin the process of collective healing that psychoanalysis and confession are supposed to provide individuals.

docs.lead_paragraph: de ALESSANDRINI di NEUENSTEIN-Dr. Luigi Maria. Died on April 10th. He was 82 and lived in New York City. Born on August 3, 1918, in Genoa, Italy. He graduated from the University of Genoa's Medical School on June 18, 1943 and received his OBGYN specialty on November 16, 1949. He served as Lt. Col. Medical Doctor during World War II in the Italian Marines. He was Health Immigration Officer from 1948-49. His interest in exploring life and seeing the world brought him to Uruguay where he met, fell in love with and married Alfa Morales on April 26, 1950. They lived in Portofino, Italy, where he practiced medicine. He was Assistant Professor of OBGYN at the University of Genoa until 1957. On April 21, 1957, he came to the US and established a private medical practice in Virginia and was on the Boards of Norfolk General and De Paul Hospitals. During his career, he also worked at Mount Vernon, Riverside and Eastern State Hospitals, where he received a specialty in Psychiatry. On May 21, 1965, Luigi was made Vice Counsel of Italy for the State of Virginia by the Italian Ministry of Commerce and Foreign Affairs and confirmed by Dean Rusk, U.S. Secretary of State. After spending 1970-73 in Italy, he returned to Virginia in 1973. In 1978 he became Assistant Professor at the Eastern Virginia Medical School. During the 70s and 80s he assisted with clinical research in the field of OBGYN, contributing to the discovery and treatment for various venereal diseases. Between 1975-1988, he became Clinical Director of the Portsmouth Health Department and was part of the National Family Planning Board, sponsored by the White House. In recognition of his contribution to special medical education programs, he was made Fellow of The American Academy of Family Physicians in October 1983. He loved his wife dearly. They have been loving friends & companions for 51 years. Alfa survives him as do his sons, Paolo and Enrico, daughters-inlaw, Jackie and Ellen and grandchildren, Alexa and Giulio. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be sent to Cabrini Hospice C/O Cabrini Medical Center, 227 East 19th Street, NY, NY, 10003.

docs.snippet: Legions of protesters have gathered in this old fortified port city to rally against globalization and the proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas, warning that eliminating tariffs and encouraging trade from the high Arctic to the Argentine pampas...
docs.lead_paragraph: Legions of protesters have gathered in this old fortified port city to rally against globalization and the proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas, warning that eliminating tariffs and encouraging trade from the high Arctic to the Argentine pampas will lead to exploitation of workers and damage to the environment. The plans for a hemispheric trade deal will be the center of attention at the third Summit of the Americas, which is to begin here Friday. But turning those plans into reality is still a long way off. The negotiations alone are expected to last until January 2005, and then the 34 countries -- every American nation except Cuba -- must individually agree to enter what would become the world's largest trade area.
